content:
So you want someone to spend an hour explaining to you how IMAP and POP work.

Fundamentally you will not have a delay with mail in your inbox in IMAP mail accojnts where the server supports push notification via the IDLE IMAP command (that iu google, others may support it. Check with your provider).

Otherwise you are limited to the frequency of mail checking in your account settings.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
For us to better investigate this issue, we will need some more information.

Could you please do the following?

  1. Open the menu > Help > Troubleshooting Information, then click Copy text to Clipboard.
  2. Go to https://pastebin.mozilla.org/, paste the clipboard by right clicking in the large text area, select paste from the menu, change the retention period to expire in 28 days, use the Paste Snippet button to create a page containing your info, then copy the resulting URL (address) of the page created.
  3. Open a reply to this post, and paste the URL to your troubleshooting information you just copied.
  4. Please also provide results for the following test on your system
    • Does Thunderbird work as expected in Thunderbird troubleshooting mode?
    • Does Thunderbird work as expected with your OS started in safe mode with Networking. Instructions for each operating system: Windows 10/11, Windows 8, Windows 7, OSX
creator: MattAuSupport

Just thinking about it, I am surprised I am using the 32-bit version as I have a 64-bit machine.

creator: MysteryMan

content:
Okay, go carefully. - first I encourage backing the profile up, just for safety. My approach is: 

  - exit thunderbird   - copy c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird  to somewhere else

- unstall thunderbird and when prompted about leaving data, allow it to stay - install the 64-bit version and start - if the profile isn't there, then exit thunderbird (important) and copy the backed up thunderbird folder to 

     c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming   to overwrite whatever is there

- restart thunderbird
creator: davidsk

creator: gregew

content:
When entering a bullet list, do this:

  1. press the bullet button on compose HTML bar above the text window
  2. enter text for the first item
  3. now, press the enter key and a new bullet line appears where you can enter second item
  4. continue pressing enter key at end of line for each item and a new bullet appears. That is, pressing the bullet button a second time at end of first entry is not the proper way to set up bulleted lists

On your other comment about the number button, it works that way so a user who clicked bullet or number and meant the other can click the desired item and Thunderbird changes as requested. It is working properly.
creator: davidsk

content: for each desired account - highlight on main view, - right-click and select 'settings' - select the copies&folders link - there you can tick the box to archive and then click the 'archive options' button to define structure. Messages can then be archived, but will not be zipped.

content: I'm still trying to learn your intent, as my response did speak to setting up individual archives per account per year. That would cause appropriate folders to be created and updated. If you want to save all messages without archiving, you might run a filter to copy all incoming mail to a local folder and the zip the folder at end of year. I do not believe you are losing mail. My suggestion is to find a way to let Thunderbird do the hard work for you; attempting to structure the process yourself causes the possible confusion we are experiencing. And, maybe it's just me..  :)

content: The hmastro account has 18 messages in inbox. Are they current or an old message. If these are both POP accounts, you can easily highlight the messages in one folder, right-click and select 'copy to' the other account. Once you've done that for all folders, you can select 'account settings', highlight the account to remove in left side of pane, scroll down slightly to 'Account Actions' menu and select 'remove account.'

creator: wssteiner

content:
Is it asking for your account password or a primary password?

In the case of a general password request, perhaps have a look at what is stored https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/password-manager-remember-delete-change-tb

I could wax lyrical on passwords for a long time, but I will limit this to there can be password issues when antivirus products are allowed to scan mail. In the first instance try disabling any email scanning.

If you have set a primary password, then there is only an option to remove it. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/protect-your-thunderbird-passwords-primary-password#w_removing-your-primary-password
creator: MattAuSupport
